intro: Oxytropis squammulosa var. purpurea, commonly known as the purple sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its hairy, gray-green foliage and showy purple or pink flowers. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, such as rocky soils and open plains. It has a taproot system that allows it to survive in dry conditions, and its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer. The species is noted for its ecological importance as a food source for various pollinators and wildlife.
